user.biography: National Geographic Explorer and NY Times photographer, creating an aerial perspective on climate change and global food supply @feedtheplanet

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by George Steinmetz on August 20, 2021. May be an image of outdoors.

node.text: Vegetable garden of Timbuktu on the edge of the Sahara in Mali.  Water is drawn up by hand pump and then carried by head-load and hand to the small plots of precious greens.  The plants are carefully fertilized and some are covered by a thin fabric to prevent sunburn and desiccation from the desert winds.  From #AfricanAirBook, autographed copies available via link in IG bio.

node.text: Ancient oasis town of Ghadames, Libya.  With no plumbing, or sanitation, residents say they were happy to move when modern housing was offered 1982, but most still maintain their ancestral homes, which are decorated with elaborate designs (2nd photo). The underground nature of the city keeps it significantly cooler than outside, and most people  slept on their roofs in the hot summer months. The city is navigated by a network of covered adobe corridors, and there are also footpaths that connect most of the rooftop sleeping areas.  Women preferred to use the rooftop walkways for social activities.  The town was largely untouched by the revolution, but gets few visitors in these unstable times.

node.text: Pen riders have to start at sunrise to check on each of 46,000 cattle in this feedlot near Happy, TX.  Any sick cows are taken to to a medical staton for treatment, and mortality rates are low, averaging 1-2% in the six months that they grow from 750 -> 1,300 lbs.. Super-sized, hyper-efficient feed lots like this are not allowed in Europe and Australia, but they have helped the U.S. to double the amount of beef produced per year with the same population of cows as we had in 1955.  To see more about where your food comes from, follow @FeedThePlanet

node.text: Alain Arnoux flying his paramotor over the mega-dunes of the Dasht-e Lut, Iran.  They say it’s the hottest place in the world, so we we thought about taking some water, but soon realized the weight would make us use more fuel, and it was safer to  go light.  #carpediem #DesertAirBook

node.text: Planet Iran: Otherworldly landscape of the Makran Coast; along the shore of the Indian Ocean; between Chabahar and the Pakistani frontier. The hills are made of gypsum-rich mud; which is is brick hard when baked by the sun; but easily eroded into spikey karst-like forms when drenched by monsoon rains.  #DesertAirBook, autographed copies available via link in IG bio.

node.text: Aerial view of the southern portion of the south lake of the Dead Sea, where waters stained brown with Potassium Sulfite cascade from one evaporation pond to another on their way to the chemical plant of the Dead Sea Works in Israel.  Their primary product is potash, exported as a component in agricultural fertilizer. From DesertAirBook, autographed copies available via link in IG bio.

node.text: Jordanian side of the Dead Sea, el. 1,400 ft., and falling.  The water level has been dropping about 3 ft./year for decades.  All of the rivers that once fed it have been tapped for human use, leaving the sea divided into two pieces by the Lisa Peninsula, seen here.

node.text: Elephants grazing in the Sudd Swamp, South Sudan, one of the last areas where African elephants can still be found outside of national parks.  At least one of the animals in this herd was darted and fitted with a radio and satellite collar by @theWCS (Wildlife Conservation Society) to get a better understanding of their seasonal migration patterns, and develop a conservation strategy.

node.text: The ancient city of Djaba, Niger, once a fortified citadel on the slave trading route to Libya, and now a haunting jumble of decaying mud architecture.  The city died not long after the abolition of the slave trade, and now is only visited seasonally to harvest the dates from the palmerie, which said to be the best in Niger.

node.text: Harvesting corn on a 40 sq mi farm in Mato Grosso, Brazil.  Due to favorable climatic conditions in the southern part of the Amazon Basin, they can get two harvests on the same field each year without irrigation.  The farm was converted from forest 21 years ago, and most of the grain is exported to China.

Photo by George Steinmetz on August 11, 2021.
Photo by George Steinmetz on August 09, 2021. May be an image of tree and nature.

node.text: Brazilian Environment Police (IBAMA) car passing through a section of the Amazon that has been converted to grazing land for cattle.  It’s illegal to cut down Brazil nut trees, which are all that remains of the original forest canopy.  Scientists are concerned that some parts of the Amazon are reaching a climatic tipping point, as savannah replaces forest that once absorbed tropical heat and slowly recycled the rain.

node.text: Dust cloud created by trucks hauling corn from the deforested Cerrado region of Brazil to a port on the Amazon River.  August is the peak of the dry season in the Amazon Basin, when the un-paved sections of BR-163 become a canal of red dust.  This narrow highway is the main artery for the settlers who have deforested the Amazon, which has led conservationists to say that paving it will only accelerate further development.
